title.narrative: EUEI PDF Energy 2014-2018 EU Energy Initiative Partnership Dialogue Facility

description.narrative: The EUEI PDF has a two-fold mission:1. to support developing countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and elsewhere in designing policies and action-oriented regional, national and sub-national strategies in order to create an enabling environment and platform for government, private sector and donor-funded investments in improved energy access, with a focus on renewable energy. This support is based on dialogue activities at all levels, supplemented by thematic studies on critical energy access topics. 2. To cooperate with the partners of the EU Energy Initiative (EUEI), especially the European Commission and EU member states, and the African partners, in the implementation of the Africa-EU Energy Partnership and other EUEI initiatives through dialogue, thematic studies and information dissemination activities.

participating-org.narrative: BMZ/Bundesministerium für wirtschaftliche Zusammenarbeit und Entwicklung
GIZ/Deutsche Gesellschaft fur Internationale Zusammenarbeit GmbH

tag.narrative: 7.1 - By 2030, ensure universal access to affordable, reliable and modern energy services.
7.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa allmän tillgång till ekonomiskt överkomliga, tillförlitliga och moderna energitjänster.

description.narrative: The EUEI PDF promotes sustainable energy for equitable development in Africa, Latin America, the Pacific region and Asia for the EU and its member states. The EUEI PDF has aimed to contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, in particular SDG7, as well as the Paris Climate Agreement. Activities have included: fostering the coherence of European development cooperation in the energy sector;? facilitating strategic political dialogue with a focus on Africa; providing policy advice, institution and capacity building services;? mobilizing and supporting private investments in renewable energy; and strengthening research, innovation & skills development in renewable energy. The EUEI PDF has four core themes: energy access, renewable energy, energy efficiency and energy security but also expanded the portfolio to cover emerging topics, such as the nexus between energy and migration; gender; sustainable cities; and climate change. The EUEI PDF was structured into four Service Lines, whose activities mutually reinforced each other and created synergies. Below are examples of results/Service line from the Final Donor Report 2015-2018. EUEI Service Line: The coherence of European development cooperation has been fostered by successfully organising 9 EUEI coordination meetings in Phase III of the EUEI PDF. With the assistance of the EUEI Service Line, the number of participating member states increased on average from 5 to 11. The majority of member states (87%) confirmed their satisfaction with the support of the EUEI Support Service Line and appreciated the improved organisation and management of EUEI coordination meetings. One example of fostering dialogue during the reporting period is the discussion forum "Enlightening the Migration Debate: the Importance of Sustainable Energy Access" (January 2017). The EUEI Service Line provided the opportunity for more than 80 participants to explore how sustainable energy can help tackle structural causes of migration and to identify opportunities and challenges for providing sustainable energy to displaced persons. The Service Line also addressed other topics of major importance, for instance by organising expert round tables to explore common approaches to monitor energy access (2016) and job creation impacts (2017). AEEP Secretariat: Since 2009, the EUEI PDF hosted the AEEP Secretariat and facilitated structured cooperation between Africa and Europe to develop shared visions, common priorities and joint actions. In Phase III of the EUEI PDF, the Secretariat organised 14 events to bring together different stakeholders of the two continents (e.g. the Second Stakeholder Forum, thematic events on energy access and security, a partner working session to job creation in Lisbon ). Thereby, the Secretariat in particular paid attention to invite an increasing number of relevant representatives from the private sector, civil society organisations and academia. In result, the participation of non-state stakeholders increased by 40%, improving opportunities for civil society and private sector to inform the political debate – and for government to mainstream strategic priorities into society.The Secretariat successfully supported the AEEP Steering Group in altogether 13 meetings to politically steer the partnership, and subsequently implemented the Steering Group’s decisions; among others, the Secretariat was tasked to outline the AEEP’s future concept, which has been approved by the Steering Group. In addition, the Secretariat played a central role in various international forums and debate, in particular presenting the views of the African and European stakeholders on energy access at the G7 in Rome, Italy April 2017.At the AU-EU Summit in November 2017, the AEEP celebrated its 10th anniversary in form of a high-level international event as part of the EU-Africa Business Forum. Stakeholders of the Partnership celebrated its achievements to-date and underlined its central role in the evolving landscape of energy in Africa. SEADS: The Service Line Strategic Energy Advisory and Dialogue Services (SEADS) has been a pioneer in supporting policy change to create favourable frameworks for sustainable energy market development in developing countries. With a wide range of experience collected over the past decade, the SEADS team supported national and municipal governments as well as regional organisations by offering complementary services to ongoing energy sector development processes in a flexible and efficient12approach. Altogether, 15 projects in different regions of the world (Africa, Central America, Pacific Island Countries, and Southeast Asia) have been finalised. The projects included more than 60 individual deliverables ranging from policy and strategy development to institution and capacity building. The advisory services of SEADS continue to be in high demand by partner countries and regions who have been issuing requests for further support measures. Continued cooperation is partly foreseen under the new service module GET.transform, to commence in Autumn 2018.With its flagship publications and studies, SEADS addressed policy makers and power sector practitioners. The publications provided guidance on how to design and implement solutions for various aspects of energy sector management and covered topics of high political relevance such as the migration debate or the energy-climate nexus. The mid-term evaluation, conducted in 2017, confirmed the lasting relevance of the publications. RECP: The RECP has been successfully positioned as an effective, demand-driven and highly flexible instrument supporting investment in decentralised renewable energy projects in Africa. Initial consultations and evaluations have shown a high rate of satisfaction among beneficiaries of the programme, and a high degree of appreciation for the ability to deliver and cooperate in a flexible and fast manner. In Phase III, advisory support by the Finance Catalyst was provided to 45 renewable energy projects representing – assuming that 50% of the projected results materialise – 187 MW of renewable energy installed capacities and € 562 million of renewable energy investment. As a result of these projects it is projected that 5.8 million end-users will have been provided with access to sustainable and reliable renewable energy supply. Projected emission reductions of 665,000 t CO2 are calculated for substitution of fossil fuels. In addition to this, the RECP has stimulated new business cooperation: more than 4,496 market participants benefited from RECP support, mainly during the 44 RECP-supported events in Phase III. RECP also undertook the organisiation of five renewable energy trade missions to RECP focus countries Mozambique, Nigeria, Rwanda, Senegal and Uganda.With its dedicated support to skills development, innovation and research cooperation, the RECP has helped setting up 2 Master programmes in Zimbabwe and Lesotho. Both Master Programmes on Renewable Energies were officially launched in January 2018. The Africa-EU research events organised by the RECP (5 in total) were well received and 9 South-South and South-North collaborations between universities have resulted out of these events so far. At the end of a 14-years journey, the accomplishments of the EUEI PDF were honoured by receiving the Alliance for Rural Electrification ‘ARE Award’ 2018 in the category 'best international & multilateral organisation' for its efforts in the field of decentralised energy access. The prize also acknowledged the EUEI PDF’s efforts to coordinate amongst the diverse actors with different backgrounds in the off-grid sector, which ARE identifies as one of the major challenges. The achievements made by the Service Lines show that the EUEI PDF accomplished most of its set objectives as stipulated in its logframe.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
